Description: Angular portion of a lead drinking-tube, with representation of a lily in the angle. The perforated bulb at one end would allow solids in the liquid to be drawn out. The other end is broken, and would probably have been significantly longer.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Amarna, el-, TA:21/477 Main City, House N.49.20 Found in the same house as the famous glass fish (EA 55193), along with two small metal vases, buried under a 'double plaster floor'.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: G. Hart, 'Eyewitness Guides: Ancient Egypt' (1990), p.48 R. E Freed, Y. J. Markowitz and S. H. D'Auria (eds.), 'Pharaohs of the Sun: Akhenaten, Nefertiti, Tutankhamun' [exhibition catalogue] (Boston/New York/London, 1999), [115] = R. Freed, 'Farao's van de Zon' (Leiden, 2000), p. 239 [115] [with photograph of a stela from Amarna showing a man using such a straw to drink from a ceramic vessel) T. Eric Peet & C. Leonard Woolley ‘et al.’, ‘The City of Akhenaten. Excavations of 1921 and 1922 at el-‘Amarneh’, Pt. I, (London 1923), p. 24, fig.5
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1999 14 Nov-2000 6 Feb, USA, Boston, Museum of Fine Arts, Pharaohs of the Sun : Akhenaten Nefertiti Tutakhamen
